post: Were grateful to TranslateLive for their support of our Civics for Everyone initiative. Their real-time translation tools ensure all students, regardless of language or ability, can access our free resources. Learn how you can support our initiative today: bit.ly/4jBYuQp  #CivicsForEveryone  #EdEquity  #LanguageAccess  #Inclusion

The Civic Star Challenge is here! 🎉 K–12 teachersintegrate the Declaration of Independence into any subject, engage your students, and compete for $200K+ in prizes. Over 300 chances to win this school year. Log your first activity today!  https://bit.ly/3V1CQuX  #CivicStarChallenge  #CivicEducation  #America250  #BRI250  #Teachers

Calling all Texas Student Changemakers! Texas MyImpact Challenge Civics Fair is headed to Dallas and we want to hear from you. Students aged 13–19 are invited to participate in-person on Saturday, September 13, 2025, at the Dallas Holocaust and Human Rights Museums, where they can showcase community service or entrepreneurship project or pitch an idea to improve your community to earn prizes ranging from $500 to $2,000. Two ways students can participate: 1. Project Trifold (for active projects): Students whove already developed community-focused initiatives can share their projects through a trifold display. Theyll explain their project, tie it back to BRIs principles and virtues,  and visually document its impact. Participants also deliver a 60–90 second elevator pitch  to the judges. 2. Pitch Competition (for ideas in progress): If a student has an idea for a civic engagement project but hasnt started yet, they can enter this track. Theyll present the concept, connect it to the founding principles and virtues, and pitch it to judges for the chance to receive up to $250 in seed funding. 📅 Sept. 13 | 9 AM–3 PM 🔗 Register now:  https://bit.ly/41boZpC Texas MyImpact Challenge is hosted by the Bill of Rights Institute thanks to our sponsor Travelers.  #CivicEducation  #StudentLeadership  #TexasStudents  #MyImpactChallenge  #StudentGrants

📜  #OTD in 1920, the 19th Amendment was ratified, securing womens right to vote. How does their pursuit of equality continue to instruct us about perseverance in civic change? Use these primary sources to help students grasp the events that led to the passage of the amendment:  https://bit.ly/4479cqv  #TDiH  #WomensSuffrage  #BRI250  #EqualRights  #CivicVirtues

Were proud to welcome FileWave as a sponsor of BRIs National Civics Teacher of the Year Award! FileWave, in partnership with TRUCE Software, an all-in-one mobile app that manages device screen time, supports school IT teams and educators with solutions that promote focus, safety, and classroom success. 📖 Read more:  https://bit.ly/45PDQIM Learn more about the FileWave and TRUCE partnership:  https://bit.ly/4mLiYbz

Imagine holding a letter signed by Lincoln or a memo penned during WWII. History By Mail brings primary sources to your mailbox each month. Use code BRI for 5% off and support our civic education mission with every order. 📬 Subscribe:  https://bit.ly/4n9iHQC  #HistoryByMail  #GiftIdeas  #HistoryEducation

What constitutional arguments did Lincoln make in the Emancipation Proclamation? What authority did he claim to issue the proclamation and what impact did it have? Find out in our newest Primary Source Essentials video on the Emancipation Proclamation. 📺 Watch the full video now:  https://bit.ly/45xEARN  #EmancipationProclamation  #CivicEducation  #Lincoln  #USHistory

Do you know a Texas student who is making a difference in their community through an act of service? Encourage them to participate in our Texas MyImpact Challenge Civics Fair sponsored by Travelers. Find out more on our event page!  https://bit.ly/4ffW2hX Open to Texas-based young people 13-19 years old.

Thank you to Periodic Presidents for supporting BRIs Civics for Everyone initiative! Their visual infographics make U. S. presidents and civic ideas more accessible for all learners, especially reluctant readers. Learn how you can support our initiative today: bit.ly/4jBYuQp  #CivicsForEveryone  #EducationForAll  #HistoryTeachers  #VisualLearning

#TDIH in 1821, Missouri entered the Union as the 24th state, sparking fierce debates over slavery and statehood. What can we learn from this moment about federalism? This essay from our U. S. History curriculum provides a helpful starting place:  https://bit.ly/45uSZz4  #TDiH  #BRI250  #AmericanHistory  #Civics  #Federalism
